profile_positions.description:
As a junior professor (W1 in Germany, similar to assistant professor), I conduct research in the field of geoinformatics, especially on topics involving spatio-temporal modelling with geosimulation models.

Geosimulation models help to understand processes in the earth system and interactions between the different components in this system, both natural and human. In addition, they can be used to project the future development of the system. Especially in the case of prediction, it is essential to understand how errors and out incomplete understanding of the system affect model outputs. The overarching goal of my research is to better quantify the predictive value of human-environment geosimulation models.

I also teach in the Master of Science Geoinformatics, and Erasmus Mundus Master of Science Geospatial Technologies. The two main courses I teach are Geosimulation Modelling and Python in GIS.

More information can be found at: https://www.uni-muenster.de/Geoinformatics/en/geosim/index.html
profile_positions.title: Junior Professor in Geoinformatics

profile_positions.description: Sim-CI develops a simulation platform (simulation as a service) to increase the resilience of critical infrastructures (electricity, water, gas etc.). As a GIS developer within the Sim-CI project team I've worked on the integration of spatial data and spatial analysis tools in the simulation platform.
profile_positions.title: GIS developer (via Ordina)

profile_positions.description:
Land use change is a central issue in the sustainability debate, because of its impacts on e.g. climate change, water availability and quality, soil quality and erosion, and biodiversity. Continuing population growth, shifting diets towards higher meat consumption and increasing bioenergy demands call for the exploration of possibilities for sustainable land use change pathways with minimal negative impacts. Land use change models are tools that support such explorations by projecting the spatial dynamics of a predefined set of land uses over a given period. My PhD research involved quantifying and reducing the uncertainty in these projections.

The thesis can be send to you upon request and can also be found here: http://dspace.library.uu.nl/handle/1874/327655
profile_positions.title: PhD student in spatio-temporal land use modelling
